column15: Can you see yourself making use of Binder in the future? If so in what capacity?
Yes, to make my code public

column13: Friendly atmosphere, the overview in the morning and code along, really useful.
column14: Can't think of anything, it was great!
column15: Yes, to share research results and for teaching.

column13: It was fun to learn how easy is to use Binder.
Good presenters. Enthusiastic. Honest in presenting limitations. Excellent overview of Turing Way.
column14: Can we see mybinder.org being used upfront first please?
column15:
Yes, both in presenting research I have been working on; and,
providing a binderhub service to our institutions researchers.

column13: The engagement and everyone following along with the building steps
column14: Additional resources to follow after the course

column13: Friendly, useful, and help / instructions available so you can go at your own pace
column15: Yes, for showing shorter machine learning projects

column13: I liked the format (a bit of introduction and background story and then half a day of hands-on coding) as well as the content: well-thought and very relevant. Presenters and helpers were all brilliant and extremely approachable.
column15: Yes. I do not do research per-se but I do some data analysis every now and then in my work that I need to share with others in my team and this would be a perfect way for them to see my results and analyses and even play with them without having to install anything themselves.

column13: good mix of seminar-based content and interaction.  Overall I thought the workshop was *fantastic*.
column14: maybe a little slower in the afternoon - possibly more time for the building your own binder bit
column15: yes - in my research - and I'm also going to teach my students how to use it!

column13: The instructions on how to build a Binder (Zero to Binder) were very good. I liked the traffic light post-it notes.
column14: Some assumptions were made regarding terminology (Markdown, commit, branch, ...). These could be explained a little for the uninitiated. Perhaps everyone understood, so this may not be an issue. There was a bit too much detail in places, but I quite like that. If the emphasis is on reproducibility then the use of targeting a commit when generating a Binder, rather than a branch or Master, should be emphasised. That said, the topic of reproducibility is wide and varied.
column15: No, at least not in the immediate future. In a few years perhaps. I work on Windows, with MATLAB and files > 2 GB, so it's not practical.
